values.alignmentText: Seoul's Han River parks and nearby Bukhansan hikes offer greenery, but dense towers and traffic mean we chase cleaner air on weekend mountain escapes.
Spring yellow dust and winter coal imports push PM2.5 into the 25–35 µg/m³ range several times a year, so we'd rely on air purifiers at home.
The 2024 minimum wage of ₩9,860/hour (~$7.40) helps service workers, yet Seoul housing makes survival tough without dual professional incomes.
Senior engineers in Pangyo Techno Valley earn ₩80–110M plus bonuses, covering city life but not matching US remote packages after taxes.
Finance, telcos, and Chaebol IT subsidiaries keep .NET teams, though Korean fluency and on-site expectations narrow Trey's options.
Rails shops are niche beyond Coupang or Woowa Brothers, so Sarah would mainly find roles at English-friendly startups or remote employers.
Hybrid arrangements exist post-pandemic, yet many Seoul teams still expect late-night syncs and regular office presence.
Seoul's 24/7 convenience stores and packed subways make daily life fast-paced, so we'd target quieter districts like Seongbuk or Bundang.
National subsidies, free preschool from age 3, and city-run care centers help citizens, but competition for Seoul daycare spots remains fierce.
Long-term foreign residents can access subsidies after registering with the local ward office, yet Korean-only paperwork and waitlists demand persistence.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries

values.alignmentText: Hongdae clubs, Gangnam lounges, and nonstop K-pop concerts give endless nightlife options for date nights.
High jeonse deposits and rising monthly rents in Gangnam and Yongsan push many families toward newer suburbs like Songdo for space.
Violent crime stays rare and late-night subways feel safe, though we remain mindful of digital scams and protest gatherings downtown.
Seoul's 23-line metro, integrated buses, and KTX bullet trains keep commutes smooth with T-money tap payments.
Transit and dining out are affordable, but private education, jeonse deposits, and imported goods raise the family budget above Kansas City norms.
Seoul hosts Nexon, NCSoft, Netmarble, and Krafton, all hiring engineers for MMOs and mobile titles, keeping Trey's prospects strong.
From Nexon's Pangyo campus to Smilegate and Pearl Abyss HQ, Seoul concentrates Asia's major studios.
Seoul Indies meetups, G-Star tie-ins, and campus e-sports clubs keep the dev community active year-round.
Government programs like Gyeonggi Content Agency grants and Seoul Startup Hub incubators support new studios, though visa rules require local partners.
Gigabit broadband, widespread 5G, and smart-city services like cashless kiosks make Seoul feel hyper-modern for a tech household.

Months of oppressive darkness or bright nights disrupt sleep cycles and make remote work or study harder to sustain. Seasonal Weather at 3/10 and Environment at 5/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for seasonal sunlight hours.

Only brief shoulder weeks feel good; most months push us indoors due to muggy, icy, or stormy conditions. Seasonal Weather at 3/10 and Environment at 5/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for pleasant weather windows.

High living costs erode quality of life; reliable childcare or healthcare coverage often falls through the cracks. Minimum Wage at 5/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Childcare Support (Citizens) at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for quality of life – lower-income tier.

Lifestyle feels brittle; one unexpected expense forces significant cutbacks or debt. Typical Software Salaries at 6/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Work-Life Balance at 4/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for quality of life – middle-income tier.

Luxury services are thin; wealth management and elite schooling often require another city. Housing Situation at 3/10, Private Education at 4/10, and Family Life at 5/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for quality of life – higher-income tier.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Spacious rentals are rare; we likely settle for smaller homes or relocate to a different metro. Housing Situation at 3/10 and Cost of Living (Optional) at 4/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for spacious housing benchmark (2k sq ft rent).

Sidewalks cover key areas but drivers often rush, so we stay alert with children. Public Transportation at 9/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Nature Access at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for walkability & pedestrian safety.

Ultra-processed options crowd shelves; schools and events lean heavily on packaged snacks. Cost of Living (Optional) at 4/10, Community Health Consciousness at 6/10, and Fresh & International Cuisine Access at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for processed food saturation.

Obesity is widespread, signaling systemic lifestyle challenges we must counter individually. Community Health Consciousness at 6/10, Work-Life Balance at 4/10, and Cost of Living (Optional) at 4/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for obesity rate.

Noticeable clusters or industrial risks require diligence and perhaps neighborhood vetting. Environment at 5/10, Healthcare (Citizens) at 8/10, and Community Health Consciousness at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for cancer incidence.

Recessions hit noticeable segments, requiring flexibility or retraining. Economic Health at 7/10, Remote-Friendly Culture at 4/10, and Typical Software Salaries at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for broader job market resilience.
